docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Albright Sketches Policy For the Middle East Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright outlined a shift in the Clinton Administration's strategy toward the Middle East, hoping to focus Israelis and Palestinians on the goal of peace rather than their myriad grievances. The change reflected Washington's acceptance Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's desire to reach an overall accord directly. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of Aetna tumbled more than 12 percent yesterday after the company, one of the nation's largest managed health care concerns, said that costs were rising faster than premiums, especially in its Medicare health maintenance organizations. Shares of Aetna fell $14.25, to $102.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the stock was one of the most heavily traded. The opening of trading in Aetna shares was delayed for nearly two hours. Shares of other H.M.O. companies were also lower.

headline.main: Aetna Stock Plunges 12% On Cost News

docs.abstract: Shares of Aetna Life and Casualty decline more than 12 percent after company, one of the nation's largest managed health care concerns, says costs are rising faster than premiums, especially in its Medicare health maintenance organizations; rising costs and company's lowered projections for growth this year reflect intensifying competition among HMO's as Aetna has reconfigured itself into managed health care company; Moody's Investors Service analyst says outlook for rising medical costs and more intense competition on prices threatens to squeeze Aetna's profit margins; HMO companies in many cities have been competing for Government dollars by offering generous benefits to elderly persons, seeking market share at expense of profits (M)
docs.snippet: Shares of Aetna tumbled more than 12 percent yesterday after the company, one of the nation's largest managed health care concerns, said that costs were rising faster than premiums, especially in its Medicare health maintenance organizations.   ...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration, a powerful yet largely invisible bureaucracy whose reach extends to every dinner table and medicine cabinet in America, is poised at the brink of fundamental, some say dangerous, change. As it contemplates expanding its vast regulatory repertory to include tobacco, critics and even some supporters are questioning whether it is up to the task. From lipstick to lemon juice, antibiotics to artificial hearts, the F.D.A. passes judgment on $1 trillion worth of products each year, accounting for 25 cents of every consumer dollar spent. Televisions and police radar guns must withstand the scrutiny of its scientists. So must condoms and donated blood. Even dog food comes under the agency's watchful eye.

headline.main: Overloaded F.D.A. Is Facing Biggest Challenge, Tobacco

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration is poised at brink of fundamental, some say dangerous, change as it contemplates expanding its vast regulatory repertory to include tobacco; prospect of new burden, stemming from tobacco industry legal settlement permitting the agency to treat nicotine as a drug, comes at a time of great uncertainty about FDA's ability to handle its current tasks and pressure to reorganize the agency; chart profiles FDA (M)
